title: Diogo Jota died in car crash after doctors told him not to fly back to united kingdom
body_text:
Diogo Jota died in car crash after doctors told him not to fly back to UK
Diogo Jota, the Liverpool FC forward, died in a car crash after doctors reportedly told him to drive 10 hours to a Spanish ferry rather than fly to the UK.
Jota was killed with his brother Andre Silva as fire engulfed his Â£180,000 Lamborghini after if suffered a tyre blowout while overtaking in the Spanish province of Zamora. The 28-year-old father-of-three had married his childhood sweetheart Rute Cardoso just 11 days earlier.
Telegraph Sport understands Jota was 190 miles into a trip from Porto to Santander because of medical advice to avoid taking a plane back to pre-season training.
Jota played 27 minutes of his countryâ€™s 2-1 win over Czech Republic last month but is said to have then undergone minor, lung-related surgery. He had suffered a rib injury while playing against Chelsea in October last season, which forced him to miss almost two months of Liverpoolâ€™s successful Premier League title charge.
It is unclear where he was given advice to avoid flying. One claimed Jota had also travelled out of the UK to his native Porto via the ferry from Plymouth to Santander.
On Thursday the football world was reeling by the â€œtragic lossâ€ of a renowned talent at the peak of his playing career. A Liverpool statement said the club was â€œdevastatedâ€ and that it was an â€œunimaginable lossâ€.
Liverpool manager Arne Slot spoke very movingly, saying: â€œWhat can anyone say at a time like this when the shock and pain is so incredibly raw? I wish I had the words but I do not.
â€œAll I have are feelings that I know so many people will share about a person and player we loved dearly and a family we care so much about.
â€œMy first thoughts are not those of a football manager. They are of a father, a son, a brother and an uncle and they belong to the family of Diogo and Andre Silva who have experienced such an unimaginable loss. My message to them is very clear â€“ you will never walk alone.
â€œThe last time we spoke, I congratulated Diogo on winning the Nations League and wished him luck for his forthcoming wedding. In many ways, it was a dream summer for Diogo and his family, which makes it all the more heartbreaking that it should end like this.
â€œWhen the time is right, we will celebrate Diogo Jota, we will remember his goals and we will sing his song. For the time being, we will remember him as a unique human being and mourn his loss.â€
The Prince of Wales, patron of the Football Association, also paid tribute, saying he was â€œdeeply saddenedâ€. Cristiano Ronaldo, the Portugal national teamâ€™s captain, said Jotaâ€™s death â€œdoesnâ€™t make senseâ€.
Jota scored 65 goals in 182 games for Liverpool, with whom he won a Premier League title, the League Cup and the FA Cup, having joined from Wolverhampton Wanderers in September 2020. He made 49 appearances for Portugal, scoring 14 goals, and was part of the side who won the Nations League last month.
Jota and his 26-year-old brother were found dead in the wreckage on the A-52 in Palacios de Sanabria shortly after midnight. Witnesses who called 112 [the local emergency number] said the car was engulfed in flames and also caused a blaze in nearby vegetation.
Sources from the government sub-delegation in Zamora immediately confirmed â€œa possible speeding incidentâ€ was being looked at. Other insiders told The Telegraph that Jotaâ€™s family had flown back to the UK separately. The car involved is believed to be a green Lamborghini Huracan Evo Spyder, which has a top speed of 200mph and 0-60mph time of 3.1 seconds. Police have yet to establish who was driving.
Jota, who was due to return to Liverpoolâ€™s pre-season training next week, had married his long-term partner two weeks ago in a Catholic service packed with family and friends in Porto.
The couple had been an item for more than a decade and had two sons and most recently a daughter born in November. He shared many family photographs on his Instagram account, while his wife has posted images of their holidays in Dubai and Lapland.
It is most likely Jota and his brother, who also played football at lower levels, were intending to board a Brittany Ferries service from Santander to Plymouth, which left at 4pm on Thursday, arriving in Devon at 11.15am on Friday.
CNN Portugalâ€™s sports editor Rui Loura had been first to report that Jota had been advised against flying. â€œThe surgery he had was lung surgery and he had been advised against flying following this,â€ Loura said. â€œHe was on his way to the northern Spanish port city of Santander to cross by ferry and reach the UK that way and carry on with the car once he reached Britain.â€ Others suggested he had previously avoided flying because of â€œpulmonary discomfortâ€.
Amid an outpouring of grief in Liverpool, fans started leaving tributes outside Anfield on Thursday â€“ with flowers being laid with messages including â€œThanks for everything, Diogoâ€.
Professor John Ashton, the former North-West public health director who became a key Hillsborough whistleblower, described the profound effect Jotaâ€™s death will have on the club. He told The Telegraph: â€œFor Liverpool FC and supporters, it is potentially triggering of the emotions we have when death visits the club and the memories that are immediately relived about Hillsborough. We share the familyâ€™s grief and if itâ€™s any comfort for the family to know: the entire community of LFC will be thinking of them and will be there as they go through this grieving. They will never walk alone.â€
Sir Kenny Dalglish, the former Liverpool manager in charge when 97 fans died in 1989, shared Prof Ashtonâ€™s sentiments. â€œFootball is not important at this sad time. You feel helpless, knowing thereâ€™s so little we can do to ease the pain for his wife of just two weeks, his three beautiful children. Thinking and praying for all their loved ones after the devastating loss of both Diogo and Andre.â€
Another former Liverpool manager, Jurgen Klopp, said on Instagram he was â€œheartbrokenâ€. His statement said: â€œThis is a moment where I struggle! There must be a bigger purpose! But I canâ€™t see it! Iâ€™m heartbroken to hear about the passing of Diogo and his brother Andre.â€ Prince Williams added: â€œOur thoughts are with his family, friends, and all who knew him.â€
Andy Robertson, his Liverpool team-mate, said: â€œThe ones Iâ€™m thinking about most right now are the family. Their loss is too much to bear. Iâ€™m so sorry that they have lost two such precious souls â€“ Diogo and Andre.
â€œI could talk about him as a player for hours, but none of that feels like it matters right now. Itâ€™s the man. The person. He was such a good guy. The best. So genuine. Just normal and real. Full of love for the people he cared about. Full of fun.
â€œThe last time I saw him was the happiest day of his life â€“ his wedding day. I want to remember his never-ceasing smile from that magical day. How much he was bursting with love for his wife and family.â€
Real Madrid player Trent Alexander-Arnold paid an emotional tribute to his former Liverpool team-mate: â€œItâ€™s so difficult to find the right words when your head and heart are struggling to accept that someone you care so much about has gone.â€
â€œDiogo, your family was your world. They were everything. For Rute, his children, and his parents, all of our hearts are broken. And for Andre as well. Brothers and best friends.
â€œWhen itâ€™s less painful, I want to remember Diogo with a big smile. So many laughs and happy moments. He was such a great team-mate and a true friend. Forever number 20. Rest in peace, Diogo.â€
Liverpool captain Virgil van Dijk shared a touching tribute. Posting on Instagram, the Dutchman said: â€œMan, I canâ€™t believe it, I donâ€™t wanna believe it.
â€œAbsolutely devastated and in total disbelief. What a human being, what a player, but most importantly what an unbelievable family man.
â€œYou meant so much to all of us and you always will! For your family to lose two sons, a husband and a father is just unimaginable.
â€œSo cruel and unfair. My heart is breaking for all of your beautiful family, for Rute and for your kids. I promise you that in these difficult times and beyond we will always be there for your family. A champion forever, number 20 forever.
â€œItâ€™s been a privilege to have stood by your side on the pitch, and to have been your friend off it. We will miss you beyond words and never forget you.
â€œYour legacy will live on, we will make sure of it! Rest in perfect peace Diogo & Andre.â€
Culture Secretary Lisa Nandy told the Commons the whole House â€œis heartbroken by this newsâ€, while Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer said Jotaâ€™s death was â€œdevastating newsâ€ and â€œthere are millions of Liverpool fans, but also football fans, and non-fans, who will also be shocked by thisâ€.
Steve Rotheram, the Metro Mayor of the Liverpool City Region, said he was â€œheartbrokenâ€ and it was a â€œhuge loss to our city and the world of footballâ€.
Zamora, close to the Portuguese border, is about halfway between Porto and the port of Santander by road. Spainâ€™s Civil Guard said â€œeverything points to a tyre blowout while overtakingâ€.
The identities of the bodies will not be fully verified until after forensic tests.
Andre Silva most recently played for Penafiel in Portugalâ€™s second division. He previously played for the youth teams of FC Porto, where his brother spent a season on loan.
